title: Episode 12 – Maureen Hart – Exec. Dir. Int’l Society of Sustainability Professionals
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[10.0s - 17.6s]: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability

[17.6s - 18.9s]: podcast series.

[19.9s - 25.3s]: We're so excited to be with you today and to share with you our guest who is Marine

[25.3s - 32.6s]: Hart, the executive director of the International Society of Sustainability Professionals.

[33.0s - 41.3s]: She's been in that role for four and a half years and has been in the arena of sustainability

[41.3s - 49.5s]: generally speaking for about 25 years in fact more than 25 years and brings an incredible

[49.5s - 57.7s]: diversity of expertise including an expertise in data management and working with sustainability

[57.7s - 64.6s]: indicators and more is the author of the guide to sustainable community indicators.

[65.1s - 68.5s]: Marina it is such a pleasure to be with you today.

[68.7s - 71.0s]: Thank you for joining us in this discussion.

[72.0s - 73.1s]: Thank you, Aaron.

[73.2s - 74.4s]: I'm delighted to be here.

[74.9s - 76.7s]: I'm really looking forward to the conversation.

[78.0s - 86.9s]: You know, I'm struck that through ISSP you are working with professionals in a variety

[86.9s - 94.8s]: of industries and sectors all over the world and what seems to be emerging there is truly

[94.8s - 95.4s]: a network.

[95.4s - 102.4s]: We can almost think of it as an ecosystem of practitioners and professionals and tell

[102.4s - 103.1s]: us about that.

[103.1s - 104.1s]: What does that look like?

[105.1s - 108.9s]: You know, it actually is wonderful to have all those connections.

[109.8s - 113.8s]: It does mean sometimes I have to get up early like this morning I had a meeting with people

[113.8s - 114.8s]: in Europe.

[115.0s - 121.1s]: It was at 7 a.m. and sometimes I have meetings with people in Asia Pacific and at the 10 p.m.

[121.3s - 127.4s]: So, but it's wonderful because these people are doing such amazing things in so many different

[127.4s - 132.0s]: industries in different countries and different aspects of sustainability.

[132.0s - 135.9s]: So, some people are working in product design.

[136.8s - 141.8s]: You know, how do we make packaging that works better is not plastic and it's not going

[141.8s - 143.9s]: to end up in the middle of a Pacific ocean?

[145.2s - 149.7s]: Or how do we make our buildings more efficient?

[150.4s - 152.4s]: Or how do we generate less waste?

[152.7s - 155.6s]: How do we make our social systems more sustainable?

[155.8s - 161.9s]: So, it's an incredibly diverse group of people and skills and it's really wonderful when

[161.9s - 163.0s]: they get together and share it.

[163.1s - 167.5s]: So, we actually now have a bullet calling regional learning networks where people are

[167.5s - 171.8s]: getting together virtual, sort of like this, where they get together.

[171.8s - 175.3s]: In fact, the meeting this morning was a group of ISSP members in Europe.

[176.8s - 182.3s]: So, with somebody in French out, somebody in Switzerland, somebody in Greece, somebody

[182.3s - 187.2s]: in the UK, and they're all having a conversation about something and sharing best practices

[187.2s - 187.9s]: with each other.

[187.9s - 195.5s]: So, it's a really wonderful, diverse and very engaged group of people.

[196.4s - 197.6s]: It's absolutely amazing.

[197.9s - 204.6s]: And just to flesh this out a little bit more for our audience, you're working with professionals

[204.6s - 212.6s]: that are in the private sector, in corporations and industry, individuals in university and

[212.6s - 217.3s]: educational sectors, the NGO sectors, and governmental sectors.

[217.3s - 217.9s]: Is that right?

[219.1s - 219.5s]: Absolutely.

[219.9s - 225.5s]: So, and people who work in hospitals or people who are trying to make municipalities more

[225.5s - 231.3s]: sustainable, working, we have some members who work for port authorities.

[231.6s - 237.1s]: So, they're working on how do you make airports or the water ports more sustainable.

[237.8s - 239.7s]: So, it's an incredibly diverse group.

[239.7s - 247.1s]: We have people working in private schools helping 10-year-olds figure out how they can

[247.1s - 249.3s]: make the world more sustainable.

[250.1s - 252.4s]: So, it's, it is incredibly diverse.

[252.6s - 255.2s]: Some people are working on communications.

[255.5s - 260.0s]: How do we get people to understand that we need to be changing what we're doing and

[260.0s - 261.8s]: improving our systems?

[263.1s - 265.9s]: You know, so it is really diverse group.

[266.3s - 272.6s]: And I guess one thing I'd like to say to your audience is regardless of what you do and

[272.6s - 277.0s]: what your interests are, you can be contributing to sustainability and should be.

[277.6s - 284.4s]: Yeah, you know, I absolutely love and resonate with that point and want to mention something

[284.4s - 285.3s]: along those lines.

[285.5s - 293.2s]: But before I forget, I want to make sure to tell our audience that ISSP runs a certification

[293.2s - 300.6s]: a credential program and Marine, you have been kind enough to extend a discount to our

[300.6s - 307.6s]: listeners, the first 25 people who sign up and join the ISSP will talk about the details

[307.6s - 309.0s]: a little bit later on.

[309.1s - 314.5s]: But just want to make sure that you all know about that special perk from today's discussion.

[315.1s - 316.2s]: And thank you for that, Marine.

[316.2s - 316.9s]: That's wonderful.

[318.0s - 318.5s]: Absolutely.

[319.1s - 319.4s]: Absolutely.

[320.1s - 328.0s]: So, yeah, to your point about how important it is, essential really that we think of the

[328.0s - 332.0s]: sustainability functions in all sectors really.

[332.2s - 338.6s]: It's something I wrote about in Y on Earth and specifically in that section, that third

[338.6s - 347.1s]: section that dealt with work and earning and our engagement with the economy and really

[347.1s - 354.8s]: thinking about how we create more cyclical and circular and regenerative economies and

[354.8s - 360.4s]: economic behavior in the broad sense of the term and that many of us, regardless of whether

[360.4s - 367.1s]: we're accountants or communications specialists or educators or manufacturers, whatever it may

[367.1s - 370.5s]: be that we're doing in terms of technical skill sets.

[371.0s - 377.5s]: More and more of us are engaging in sustainability and stewardship through all those different

[377.5s - 377.9s]: channels.

[377.9s - 385.9s]: And it seems that you are at such an amazing nexus point of that fast emerging and growing

[385.9s - 386.5s]: phenomenon.

[389.1s - 389.8s]: Absolutely.

[390.7s - 400.3s]: And our members are engaging in a key part of what they do is work to engage others in

[400.3s - 406.9s]: their organizations or in their communities and try and figure out how to get everybody

[406.9s - 413.2s]: involved in this because it's not something that one person in an organization can solve.

[413.5s - 419.0s]: Everybody has a part to play, whether in a business, if you're the purchasing manager,

[419.2s - 424.8s]: then you need to be thinking about where are the products you are purchasing coming from?

[425.0s - 425.9s]: How have they been sourced?

[426.0s - 428.0s]: Are they renewable products?

[428.2s - 430.3s]: Are they compostable?

[430.5s - 432.7s]: What happens to them at the end of their life cycle?

[433.2s - 434.5s]: How are they being produced?

[435.4s - 440.3s]: Is there slave labor or child labor being used to produce them?

[440.8s - 443.4s]: Is there a lot of pollution generated when they're produced?

[443.8s - 449.5s]: The purchasing person has to think about it, but also the HR person has to think about

[449.5s - 453.5s]: it because they have to make sure that everyone in the company is trained on sustainability

[453.5s - 455.8s]: and understand how it fits into what they're doing.

[456.4s - 458.9s]: Everyone has a piece that they can play.

[461.2s - 466.7s]: What's really wonderful is the training courses that we have help people understand where

[466.7s - 468.8s]: they fit into that, but also what they can do.

[469.0s - 471.8s]: Right now, we're running a course on sustainability planning.

[472.6s - 476.7s]: Next month, we're doing one on sustainability management systems because it's one thing

[476.7s - 477.4s]: to do with plan.

[478.7s - 483.6s]: If you don't have a system in place to actually implement the plan and make sure that you

[483.6s - 487.2s]: then, any plan that you put in place, you then have to do it.

[487.2s - 491.4s]: Then at the end, you have to check to make sure that you've had some results and revised

[491.4s - 491.8s]: it.

[492.3s - 493.8s]: There's a whole process for that.

[494.2s - 499.8s]: The next step is on leadership skills, how you can be a change agent within your organization

[499.8s - 501.1s]: or within your municipality.

[505.2s - 511.6s]: That's part of what we do is empower the professionals to be able to make change.

[512.5s - 520.2s]: It's so beautiful and to be able to provide expertise and methodologies that help folks

[520.2s - 527.0s]: really up their game, up level their capability is obviously such a huge value.

[527.3s - 532.0s]: It's clear that the market is shifting more and more in this direction and that folks

[532.0s - 539.4s]: who have not only the credentials, but the access to the additional resources and capabilities

[539.4s - 542.8s]: are going to have additional competitive advantage out there, basically.

[544.3s - 544.8s]: Absolutely.

[545.1s - 550.2s]: In fact, on our website, we have recordings of webinars that we've done recently with

[551.9s - 553.7s]: potential holders in different industries.

[554.0s - 559.0s]: We have one for people that are in higher education, one for credential holders in local

[559.0s - 561.7s]: government and two that are for consultants.

[562.2s - 571.8s]: They talk about what they feel is the value of the credential in furthering their career,

[572.4s - 579.2s]: but also in how getting the credentials helps them to better understand what they were

[579.2s - 581.2s]: doing and have better skills to do it.

[581.7s - 587.0s]: Actually, they also talk a little bit about their journey, how they got to those points

[587.0s - 587.6s]: in their life.

[587.6s - 590.3s]: That's actually a lot of fun to listen to as the trajectory of it.

[590.4s - 597.3s]: We have one person who got a degree in philosophy and now we have a facilities manager.

[597.8s - 600.0s]: We have someone else who got a degree in religion.

[600.9s - 602.0s]: It's just amazing.

[602.6s - 606.1s]: There are people that got degrees in engineering or in journalism.

[607.0s - 612.9s]: It's really an amazingly diverse group and it's just fun to listen to how they got where

[612.9s - 613.7s]: they are today.

[614.4s - 618.8s]: I think it inspires everyone to see that they can do it as well.

[619.6s - 620.2s]: So beautiful.

[620.4s - 628.0s]: Well, I guess we could quip that perhaps all roads can lead to sustainability and hopefully

[628.0s - 628.5s]: will.

[629.3s - 630.8s]: Yes, and they all need to.

[631.5s - 631.9s]: Absolutely.

[632.1s - 632.4s]: I agree.

[632.8s - 635.8s]: Let me ask you about your journey, speaking of journeys.

[635.8s - 642.0s]: How did you end up as the executive director of ISSP?

[642.4s - 643.4s]: Tell us about that.

[644.9s - 654.4s]: You know, I started off an information management and was doing database work for the USEPA,

[655.2s - 659.7s]: particularly in the area of hazardous materials management.

[659.9s - 661.1s]: So they had a database on that.

[661.9s - 667.8s]: And I decided I needed to go get a degree in that area because I didn't really, I knew

[667.8s - 671.8s]: it was bad stuff but I didn't really understand all the issues with it.

[672.0s - 676.5s]: So I went back to school to get a master's in hazardous materials management in civil

[676.5s - 677.7s]: and environmental engineering.

[678.6s - 683.4s]: And while I was there at Sufts University, there was a group of people working on sustainable

[683.4s - 684.6s]: community indicators.

[685.2s - 687.5s]: And I thought, oh, indicators, I do data.

[687.6s - 688.3s]: I know how about that.

[688.3s - 694.3s]: And what I wanted to do is, you know, the problem with data and indicators is people go,

[694.5s - 698.6s]: oh, we've got to measure everything so we know what to do next.

[698.7s - 701.7s]: And the problem is you never have enough data.

[702.5s - 707.4s]: And if you spend all of your time collecting more and more data, you know, what I call feeding

[707.4s - 711.2s]: the data monster, you'll never actually make a decision.

[711.5s - 713.4s]: You'll never actually start doing anything.

[714.0s - 719.1s]: So I said, you know, I could help communities that are working on sustainability, help them

[719.1s - 724.8s]: think about why they want to measure something and help them define the real goals they want

[724.8s - 728.3s]: and then what's the least amount of data that they want to collect.

[728.6s - 734.0s]: So I ended up writing the guy, the sustainable community indicators and then did a lot of

[734.0s - 735.5s]: work with the US EPA.

[735.8s - 742.1s]: I did a bunch of training trainers around the country on what is the sustainability indicator

[742.1s - 747.4s]: and how do you use it and, you know, how do you decide what the right ones for your community

[747.4s - 749.6s]: also work with the US Forest Service.

[750.3s - 755.5s]: And then I got involved with, I was a member of IASP and I got involved with some work

[755.5s - 760.5s]: with two of the founders put together, a sustainability assessment tool that was very

[760.5s - 761.0s]: high level.

[762.2s - 769.6s]: And I called a cross between a Myers-Briggs organization and a reading readiness because

[769.6s - 775.3s]: what it does is it looks at an organization and says, you know, of all the different

[775.3s - 779.9s]: functions you have in the organization, you've got senior management, HR and purchasing

[779.9s - 781.1s]: and facilities managers.

[781.8s - 787.7s]: They're all doing something and they all have different roles to play and each of those

[787.7s - 793.5s]: roles has different levels that they could be at and they could be at, you know, not even

[793.5s - 798.7s]: starting or they could be really, you know, well along the path as sort of a maturity model.

[799.2s - 804.3s]: And so I started using that model with a bunch of my clients and it was really wonderful

[804.3s - 808.8s]: because we could benchmark and say, okay, you know, in this particular area on say purchasing,

[808.9s - 810.9s]: you're doing really well because you're thinking about it.

[811.4s - 816.9s]: But you know, in terms of educating your employees or having a vision for the corporation,

[816.9s - 818.0s]: you're really not that far.

[818.4s - 824.4s]: So it was a wonderful way to help organizations figure out where they could really have the

[824.4s - 827.6s]: most impact or what they really needed to work on most.

[828.3s - 833.1s]: And the point was not that everybody would get every one of those things to be perfect,

[833.4s - 834.0s]: right?

[834.2s - 838.5s]: You know, the example I always use is, I'm never going to be a good basketball player.

[838.9s - 841.7s]: I'm too short and I'm really not that coordinated.

[842.2s - 844.6s]: But there's other things that I do really well, right?

[844.7s - 846.5s]: And so that's what sustainability is about.

[846.6s - 851.5s]: Every organization has different ways that they're impacting the world in terms of sustainability

[852.3s - 853.6s]: and that's what they should focus on.

[853.6s - 857.4s]: So if you're a law firm, your water use is probably minimal.

[858.2s - 861.9s]: But you may have a lot of pay per use or you may have a lot of travel.

[862.8s - 869.0s]: Whereas if you're a food processor, your water use and your food waste is probably really high,

[869.3s - 871.3s]: you may not have a lot of travel, right?

[871.5s - 872.9s]: So it helps to people.

[873.3s - 875.3s]: So this is actually the longer story, right?

[875.7s - 879.4s]: So I got involved in that and used that tool.

[879.5s - 882.2s]: And now that's actually one of the tools that I as the team has.

[882.2s - 886.6s]: And then it's four and a half years ago, one of the founders who was the executive director

[886.6s - 890.0s]: at the time decided to step down and I threw my hat in the ring.

[890.2s - 890.7s]: And here I am.

[891.4s - 891.9s]: Wonderful.

[892.6s - 898.5s]: Well, I want to ask you a couple of questions getting a bit more into some of the

[899.5s - 903.3s]: details around the value and the services that you offer.

[903.5s - 909.3s]: But before I do that, I just, I have to ask, and I do this with some of my

[910.0s - 915.8s]: consulting clients, whether they're executives of larger companies and organizations or

[915.8s - 919.1s]: entrepreneurs with early stage ventures.

[920.4s - 926.6s]: Outside of your work, part of your life, in your personal part of your life,

[927.0s - 934.3s]: how do you incorporate some of the opportunities for stewardship and sustainability that

[935.0s - 937.6s]: perhaps reflects what you're doing professionally?

[937.8s - 941.9s]: In other words, if we were to take a walk with Marie on the weekend or something,

[942.2s - 943.2s]: what does that look like?

[944.5s - 946.6s]: Well, actually, you'd have to have a bike.

[947.2s - 947.5s]: Okay.

[949.6s - 954.2s]: Because what I like to do is take bike rides and I actually do try to bike to work.

[956.3s - 962.1s]: I also, I'm more apt to be walking in the woods than going shopping.

[963.5s - 967.4s]: And one of the things that I've been doing over the last few years is down-cliving.

[968.8s - 974.1s]: Figuring out what's the least I need in terms of material goods to really survive.

[974.3s - 979.7s]: Because in fact, it's the people you have around you and the friends and families that you

[979.7s - 981.2s]: have that really makes life worth living.

[982.5s - 988.6s]: You know, this idea of, you know, she who has the most toys wins when they die, it's like,

[988.6s - 989.5s]: no, it's not it.

[989.9s - 991.7s]: It's the friends and family that are around you.

[992.0s - 998.2s]: So, you know, that's the, and, you know, obviously things like reducing water use,

[998.4s - 999.0s]: reducing waste.

[999.6s - 1002.5s]: I try to only buy organic food.

[1003.7s - 1008.1s]: And although it don't, the moment has my own garden.

[1008.7s - 1010.3s]: I actually just moved to Pittsburgh.

[1010.3s - 1013.5s]: And when I was living in Connecticut, I was part of a CSA.

[1014.1s - 1018.1s]: I was one of the managing organizers of a CSA.

[1018.1s - 1021.9s]: It was providing organic food to the local community.

[1022.6s - 1023.6s]: Oh, that's wonderful.

[1023.9s - 1024.8s]: That is just wonderful.

[1025.0s - 1026.6s]: Thank you for sharing that.

[1026.7s - 1030.4s]: I can, I can form a picture in my mind as you're describing that.

[1031.4s - 1031.9s]: Beautiful.

[1032.4s - 1038.6s]: And of course, in Pittsburgh, there are plenty of wonderful forested walking trails.

[1038.8s - 1042.0s]: I understand it's one of the more forested park

[1044.4s - 1046.1s]: rich cities in our country.

[1047.0s - 1048.6s]: There are some great parks.

[1048.9s - 1049.0s]: Yes.

[1050.0s - 1054.8s]: Very newly, so bike riding is not as easy as it was in Connecticut,

[1055.2s - 1057.1s]: but it's still a lot of fun.

[1057.7s - 1059.9s]: And they actually have wonderful rail trails here.

[1061.2s - 1062.6s]: That's a really great advantage.

[1063.3s - 1063.7s]: Beautiful.

[1064.4s - 1064.8s]: Well, cool.

[1065.0s - 1065.4s]: Thank you for sharing that.

[1065.4s - 1069.0s]: And there's actually a lot of sustainability going on in Pittsburgh.

[1070.2s - 1072.0s]: There's a group called Sustainable Pittsburgh

[1072.0s - 1076.1s]: that I actually happen to do some consulting for about 10 years ago before I had this

[1076.1s - 1077.7s]: job when I had a consulting company.

[1078.6s - 1081.3s]: And they have a sustainable restaurant program.

[1081.8s - 1086.7s]: And one of the things that just recently they started putting on the bus stops,

[1086.8s - 1088.8s]: you know, then they had to add on the bus stop.

[1089.3s - 1093.4s]: They have a picture of a person eating something and it says, you know,

[1093.6s - 1096.4s]: Aaron eats that like sustainable food.

[1096.6s - 1098.2s]: And so he's a sustainable restaurant.

[1098.7s - 1101.2s]: This is just advertising around the town.

[1101.7s - 1102.4s]: Love it.

[1102.5s - 1105.0s]: And it says it's just wonderful things going on here.

[1105.6s - 1113.0s]: Well, there's certainly a particular power that food holds in connecting us more

[1113.0s - 1116.4s]: and more with soil and sustainability stewardship.

[1116.7s - 1126.2s]: I want to ask of the many, many, many leaders and projects you're familiar with through

[1126.9s - 1133.7s]: leading the ISSP, are there a couple that jump out at you as really wonderful examples,

[1133.7s - 1137.8s]: success stories that we might share with our audience?

[1140.1s - 1145.1s]: You know, I wouldn't want to say, oh, there's one or two because there are hundreds.

[1146.0s - 1150.4s]: But I think there are some wonderful examples that I would love to give.

[1153.3s - 1155.4s]: One of them happens to be the president of the board.

[1155.8s - 1161.5s]: He works for a company called HoloFresh, which is one of the food kit delivery services.

[1161.5s - 1166.4s]: And what they're doing is trying to figure out, you know, you get the box and it's got

[1166.4s - 1172.8s]: cold packs in it and, you know, it's got this packaging and what he's working on is how do we

[1172.8s - 1176.1s]: reduce the packaging so there's less impact there?

[1177.0s - 1184.2s]: But then also, how do we make sure that the food that's being provided organically grown responsibly

[1184.2s - 1188.7s]: sourced? So, you know, there's a whole lot of work going on around that.

[1189.6s - 1193.2s]: You know, we have another member who works for Proctor and Gamble.

[1193.9s - 1197.1s]: And he's working to make their products more sustainable.

[1198.4s - 1199.0s]: Of course.

[1199.3s - 1201.4s]: We had, I'm sorry.

[1201.8s - 1205.5s]: I was just going to mention, of course, for folks who may not be aware of Proctor and Gamble,

[1205.6s - 1210.8s]: P&G is one of the largest consumer package goods companies in the world.

[1210.9s - 1216.0s]: So that's a place where that individual is hopefully able to have substantial impact.

[1216.8s - 1217.3s]: Right.

[1218.0s - 1218.0s]: 

[1218.5s - 1222.0s]: Yeah. And so actually, you know, there's another member who was working in packaging

[1222.8s - 1230.6s]: and has some great stories about how, how do we make the packaging more sustainable?

[1231.3s - 1236.6s]: But the reason you have the packaging is so that the food stays fresh, right?

[1236.8s - 1241.5s]: So because if you and coffee is a really great example to choose, you know, those little

[1242.4s - 1247.3s]: coffee packs and like the curing machines, it seems really wasteful.

[1248.0s - 1252.0s]: And it'd be great. We actually in this co-work space that I mean, we have

[1253.2s - 1258.2s]: little pods that are mostly fabric, not the plastic thing. So that's an improvement.

[1258.9s - 1266.2s]: But her point was that growing coffee and then shipping it all the way to the US takes a whole

[1266.2s - 1272.1s]: lot of energy. If you end up having to throw coffee out because of your wasting it, then

[1273.8s - 1279.7s]: that's an unsustainable process. So that's one of these sustainability is a bad balance.

[1280.3s - 1284.0s]: How do we figure out the best way to do it? I mean, we could all just give up coffee.

[1285.4s - 1289.1s]: Right. Because then we wouldn't have to transport it. But then the people in those areas that

[1289.1s - 1294.1s]: are growing it wouldn't have jobs. You know, sustainability is about the system. We have to think

[1294.1s - 1300.0s]: about all those features. The other example that she gave me was bananas. You know, at one point,

[1300.1s - 1305.3s]: the company decided to wrap their bananas in plastic. And everyone was up in arms. It's like,

[1305.5s - 1311.0s]: bananas don't need plastic. But in fact, this plastic kept them from overwiping.

[1311.6s - 1317.2s]: Yeah. And so the food waste out. Yeah. That way it was a waste. Right. But

[1318.4s - 1322.1s]: that's one of the issues about sustainability. You really have to think about

[1323.2s - 1327.4s]: how do you work with all the stakeholders? In that case, they hadn't worked with consumers

[1328.5s - 1334.4s]: to get them to understand why having plastic would work. So they ended up not doing that anymore.

[1334.5s - 1340.0s]: So, you know, sustainability is really complex. And there's a lot of education that we need to do.

[1340.6s - 1344.7s]: And we need to really bring in all of the different stakeholders to make sure that the

[1344.7s - 1351.7s]: solutions we come up with are going to work. I love that through the International Society of

[1351.7s - 1357.4s]: Sustainability Professionals with you and your colleagues. You are bringing together so many

[1357.4s - 1364.8s]: experts and expertise. And it seems like it's one of those must-have relationships and resources

[1364.8s - 1372.0s]: for more and more of us who are engaged in this sustainability work. And I want to mention

[1372.7s - 1380.1s]: that to our audience, as a reminder, you're tuned into the Yon Earth communities, stewardship

[1380.1s - 1387.0s]: and sustainability series, our podcast series. And today we are speaking with Marine Hart,

[1387.2s - 1392.8s]: the Executive Director of the International Society of Sustainability Professionals. And

[1392.8s - 1402.3s]: Marine has shared a very special offer to us for this podcast episode, which is a code Yon Earth.

[1402.3s - 1410.7s]: If you go to sustainabilityprofessionals.org and click on the button to join the first 25 people

[1410.7s - 1419.1s]: who do so will get a $25 discount using the code Yon Earth as they engage and look at becoming

[1419.1s - 1427.5s]: members and potentially getting the credential to certification as well. I also want to mention that

[1428.3s - 1436.4s]: on the Yon Earth.org website, specifically Yon Earth.org slash market, we have a whole bunch of

[1436.4s - 1444.3s]: books and other products, printed books, audiobooks, ebooks. And for those of you tuning in,

[1444.4s - 1450.8s]: if you want to use the code there, the code podcast, you can get a nice discount on the ebooks

[1450.8s - 1456.1s]: and audiobook products that we have available for you there. So just want to make sure everybody

[1456.1s - 1461.4s]: knows about those resources. And Marine, thanks again for that generous discount. It's wonderful.

[1462.5s - 1467.6s]: Absolutely. I just want to clarify it's Yon Earth, but it's a capital Y in the rest of the

[1467.6s - 1473.6s]: letters you're in lowercase. Oh, good to know. Okay, I'll make sure that's clear in the show notes as well.

[1475.5s - 1483.1s]: I want to ask, you know, as you're building this global network of experts, practitioners and

[1483.7s - 1492.1s]: folks who are upping our games, what are one or two of the biggest challenges that you're seeing

[1492.8s - 1497.5s]: for us professionals as well as for our society's generally speaking?

[1499.2s - 1504.5s]: You know, the biggest we actually just did a survey of all of our members and this is one of

[1504.5s - 1510.8s]: the questions we asked them. And one of the biggest issues they said was the lack of awareness

[1511.8s - 1517.5s]: of the size and the scope of the sustainability issues and the need for action right now. And this

[1517.5s - 1525.7s]: is particularly a problem given the current political climate. You know, what we really need is more

[1525.7s - 1532.3s]: collaboration and cooperation in order to solve some of these problems. You know, and on the

[1532.3s - 1540.5s]: environmental side, we've got massive hurricanes and wildfires and floods and you're in

[1540.5s - 1545.3s]: Pittsburgh, we're having lots of landslides because of torrential rains. And so all of those

[1545.3s - 1552.3s]: things are caused by the climate change. But we also have other things happening like a declining

[1552.3s - 1560.5s]: pollinator populations, you know, honey bees. And the things that we need to pollinate the food that

[1560.5s - 1567.3s]: we eat. And so this is changing our whole food ecosystem, which is going to be a problem. And then

[1567.3s - 1574.2s]: on the social side, there are issues with increasing income inequality and lack of trust and cooperation.

[1575.3s - 1583.6s]: And that's what makes a democracy function. And so we really need to start working on those and

[1583.6s - 1589.7s]: and so getting awareness out to people and finding ways to talk to each other. So that's really

[1589.7s - 1597.6s]: one of the biggest ones. The other issue is that a lot of people think that sustainability is all

[1597.6s - 1602.3s]: about the environment. Right. And what I like to tell people is, you know,

[1603.4s - 1609.8s]: Mother Nature is going to be around long after we're gone. Sustainability is really about our economic

[1609.8s - 1618.1s]: and our social system. And we have to understand that it's a system. And so we have to figure out how do

[1618.1s - 1624.3s]: we make our social system and our economic system work within the environmental system that's there.

[1624.5s - 1633.4s]: Because, you know, it's the laws of nature that are really, you can't repeal them. Right. Gravity

[1634.6s - 1641.8s]: exists. You can't repeal the law of gravity. And you can't change the way nature works. So we really

[1641.8s - 1647.4s]: need to think about how do we change the economic and social system. Then

[1650.0s - 1656.4s]: one of the important things is to realize the social aspects of it because poverty and income

[1656.4s - 1664.0s]: inequality are really driving a lot of the issues that we have. You know, we in the US have a very

[1664.0s - 1669.8s]: high standard of living. And it's not right for us to turn around to someone in a low-income country

[1669.8s - 1673.9s]: and say, no, no, no, you can't you can't have any of the things that we have.

[1674.5s - 1678.7s]: Especially if these people can't, you know, feed their families. If you can't

[1679.3s - 1684.9s]: care for your basic needs, take care of your kids, you're not going to care if the factory starts up

[1684.9s - 1690.6s]: that's polluting the environment, right? Because that's a longer term issue. And you just want to

[1690.6s - 1696.5s]: feed your kids so you want a job. Right. So we need to think about how do we make the economic

[1696.5s - 1702.6s]: system and the social system fit together. So that's the other thing is that people not realizing

[1702.6s - 1711.7s]: that social and economic issues are really the sustainability challenge. Another one is short-term

[1711.7s - 1719.2s]: thinking. Yes. And a lack of a system of view. Right. Understanding that these things are connected.

[1719.8s - 1729.1s]: You know, for example, in our in the corporate world, most companies are driven by quarterly earnings

[1729.1s - 1737.9s]: reports. And that means it's really hard to make a decision that if we make this change to our

[1737.9s - 1743.8s]: process, which is going to have a really great reduction in, say, carbon emissions are waste.

[1744.5s - 1751.8s]: But it's going to be an economic payback that will take 10 years. Then they may not do it because

[1752.4s - 1757.1s]: the shareholders are going to say, wait a minute, we need more profit. Right. So there's that short-term

[1757.6s - 1763.7s]: thinking that we need to step back from and say, you know, it's okay. And that's actually one of

[1763.7s - 1769.1s]: the things that's happening is there are companies called B-Corp's that are benefit corporations

[1769.1s - 1776.9s]: being created where they're actually now, I don't know, like 40 states have a legislation that

[1776.9s - 1784.0s]: allows them. And that's allowing companies to be set up so they can say, yes, we need to give

[1784.0s - 1788.7s]: benefits to our shareholders, but we can also think of social and environmental benefits. And

[1788.7s - 1793.6s]: that will count as well. So that's another interesting change that's happening. And then finally,

[1793.6s - 1800.9s]: the last really major challenge that sustainability professionals have is making the business case

[1800.9s - 1809.2s]: for sustainability. I was just talking about how do you put in some program in place that's

[1809.2s - 1815.4s]: going to have a 10-year payback. Well, part of the problem is, we have these hurricanes and

[1815.4s - 1822.8s]: floods and landslides and the cost of fixing all of that doesn't get factored into the price of

[1822.8s - 1829.8s]: oil or the price of energy, you know, or the cost of goods. So any pollution that's created in

[1829.8s - 1836.2s]: China to create low-cost goods that we then buy doesn't get factored into the price, but you know,

[1836.3s - 1841.3s]: there are now some poor air quality days in California that are caused by pollution in China.

[1841.9s - 1847.5s]: It's a system and we need to think about that. So how do we create these business cases

[1847.5s - 1853.5s]: and be able to factor in what those are called externalities, how those costs that we don't usually

[1853.5s - 1859.6s]: think of. So those are really the biggest sort of global problems. The individual problems for

[1859.6s - 1865.2s]: the sustainability professionals themselves, you know, what is sort of isolation because a lot of

[1865.2s - 1869.3s]: companies have one sustainability professional that's known to talk to. And that's one of the reasons

[1870.0s - 1875.4s]: ISSP is a great organization because you can network with other people. You can talk about issues

[1875.4s - 1878.8s]: you're having and someone will say, oh yeah, you know, I tried that, it didn't really work,

[1878.9s - 1883.4s]: so I did this instead. So there's being able to work with other people,

[1886.3s - 1890.7s]: expanding responsibility for sustainability, you know, getting it so it's not just, oh, you're

[1890.7s - 1895.9s]: the sustainability director, you fix the problem. It's everybody's responsibility. So how do you

[1895.9s - 1901.1s]: expand it and bring in all of the stakeholders and all of the people within the organization?

[1901.1s - 1906.9s]: And that gets to changing corporate culture. And so that's another big challenge that the

[1906.9s - 1914.2s]: individual has. How do you manage culture change within organizations? And then there's just resources.

[1915.5s - 1922.0s]: You know, getting the resources to put new projects in place, but also to maintain projects

[1922.0s - 1931.1s]: that you've already had going for a few years. And this is actually something that we hear in the

[1931.1s - 1935.2s]: poll because we put a whole lot of effort, oh, you know, put a whole lot of money into building this

[1935.2s - 1941.7s]: bridge and then didn't think about how much it was going to cost to maintain it. So we need to

[1941.7s - 1946.1s]: be better at thinking about this. Again, that gets to the long-term planning. Yeah.

[1946.3s - 1951.3s]: Long-term thinking is building the road is great, but then we're just going to cost to fix it.

[1952.2s - 1957.6s]: So those are a lot of the issues that figure issues and then individual issues.

[1958.4s - 1966.2s]: Thank you so much for walking us through that. And I'm just going to encourage our audience.

[1966.4s - 1971.4s]: Whatever it is you're doing, maybe you're an entrepreneur, or maybe you're working with a large

[1971.4s - 1980.2s]: corporation or a university. Check out the ISSP SustainabilityProfessionals.org. And be sure to

[1980.2s - 1985.3s]: take advantage of the discount code that Marine has offered. You know, as you were describing

[1985.3s - 1993.3s]: Marine the perspective that says sustainability is about our economic and social systems. I couldn't

[1993.3s - 2002.2s]: help but hear some unspoken words threading through this. Words like empathy and care. And dare I say

[2002.2s - 2010.0s]: love. I'm daring to say love more and more actually. It's curious to me looking at what the

[2010.0s - 2015.6s]: largest corporations are beginning to show in the way of shifts and changes certainly where

[2016.3s - 2023.2s]: consumer demand is shifting in a dramatic way. It seems to me that although the last 20, 25,

[2023.3s - 2029.4s]: 30 years have been marked by some deep institutional challenges to some of the positive changes

[2029.4s - 2036.4s]: we're describing now, it's very clear that the companies and organizations that don't start moving

[2036.4s - 2042.6s]: rapidly in the direction of sustainability are actually potentially exposing themselves to

[2042.6s - 2052.0s]: enormous risks. Risks of market share loss, risks of loss of relevance, risks of not looking like

[2052.0s - 2058.1s]: they're taking their responsibilities as fiduciaries, their responsibilities vis-à-vis diligence,

[2058.7s - 2064.9s]: their leadership responsibilities seriously. And as the world's waking up to this, I believe we're at

[2064.9s - 2071.5s]: such a potent nexus point. It's very exciting and it means to me that more and more of us are

[2071.5s - 2077.9s]: going to need resources like ISSP to get the jobs done that we have in front of us.

[2079.1s - 2085.8s]: Yeah, absolutely. And companies need to look at the risks because as we have more sustainability

[2086.4s - 2091.6s]: problems like huge hurricanes, you're going to have problems with your supply. Your supply

[2091.6s - 2095.5s]: chain is going to get broken. You're not going to be able to create the goods that you're trying to

[2095.5s - 2103.2s]: survive, to use it to manage your company. And so it's really important that companies look at all

[2103.2s - 2110.5s]: of those sustainability aspects. You're absolutely right. Yeah, absolutely, Marie. Well, I want to thank you

[2110.5s - 2117.4s]: for joining us today for this discussion. And I know that there's a whole lot more we could be

[2117.4s - 2124.3s]: talking about. And I hope we have the opportunity to engage more deeply over the coming weeks and

[2124.3s - 2133.1s]: months. And I'll give you the opportunity if there's any final message or thought you'd like to

[2133.1s - 2141.2s]: share with the audience before we wrap up. Please do. You know, I definitely want to encourage people

[2141.2s - 2147.9s]: if they're in any sort of professional area to think about the coming of sustainability professional

[2147.9s - 2152.7s]: or thinking at least about how you can incorporate that into what you're doing because there is

[2152.7s - 2158.1s]: something in your job that you can make better. And also think about how you can do it

[2158.1s - 2162.9s]: within your community because that's important. Getting the word out there and getting people

[2162.9s - 2169.9s]: to think more about how do we make better communities and get involved. Just get involved.

[2170.8s - 2175.4s]: Beautiful. Love it. Well, Maureen, thank you so much for joining us today. It's been an

[2175.4s - 2180.1s]: absolute pleasure talking with you. Thank you, Aaron. I've enjoyed it very much.

segments.text: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability
podcast series.
We're so excited to be with you today and to share with you our guest who is Marine
Hart, the executive director of the International Society of Sustainability Professionals.
She's been in that role for four and a half years and has been in the arena of sustainability
generally speaking for about 25 years in fact more than 25 years and brings an incredible
diversity of expertise including an expertise in data management and working with sustainability
indicators and more is the author of the guide to sustainable community indicators.
Marina it is such a pleasure to be with you today.
Thank you for joining us in this discussion.
Thank you, Aaron.
I'm delighted to be here.
I'm really looking forward to the conversation.
You know, I'm struck that through ISSP you are working with professionals in a variety
of industries and sectors all over the world and what seems to be emerging there is truly
a network.
We can almost think of it as an ecosystem of practitioners and professionals and tell
us about that.
What does that look like?
You know, it actually is wonderful to have all those connections.
It does mean sometimes I have to get up early like this morning I had a meeting with people
in Europe.
It was at 7 a.m. and sometimes I have meetings with people in Asia Pacific and at the 10 p.m.
So, but it's wonderful because these people are doing such amazing things in so many different
industries in different countries and different aspects of sustainability.
So, some people are working in product design.
You know, how do we make packaging that works better is not plastic and it's not going
to end up in the middle of a Pacific ocean?
Or how do we make our buildings more efficient?
Or how do we generate less waste?
How do we make our social systems more sustainable?
So, it's an incredibly diverse group of people and skills and it's really wonderful when
they get together and share it.
So, we actually now have a bullet calling regional learning networks where people are
getting together virtual, sort of like this, where they get together.
In fact, the meeting this morning was a group of ISSP members in Europe.
So, with somebody in French out, somebody in Switzerland, somebody in Greece, somebody
in the UK, and they're all having a conversation about something and sharing best practices
with each other.
So, it's a really wonderful, diverse and very engaged group of people.
It's absolutely amazing.
And just to flesh this out a little bit more for our audience, you're working with professionals
that are in the private sector, in corporations and industry, individuals in university and
educational sectors, the NGO sectors, and governmental sectors.
Is that right?
Absolutely.
So, and people who work in hospitals or people who are trying to make municipalities more
sustainable, working, we have some members who work for port authorities.
So, they're working on how do you make airports or the water ports more sustainable.
So, it's an incredibly diverse group.
We have people working in private schools helping 10-year-olds figure out how they can
make the world more sustainable.
So, it's, it is incredibly diverse.
Some people are working on communications.
How do we get people to understand that we need to be changing what we're doing and
improving our systems?
You know, so it is really diverse group.
And I guess one thing I'd like to say to your audience is regardless of what you do and
what your interests are, you can be contributing to sustainability and should be.
Yeah, you know, I absolutely love and resonate with that point and want to mention something
along those lines.
But before I forget, I want to make sure to tell our audience that ISSP runs a certification
a credential program and Marine, you have been kind enough to extend a discount to our
listeners, the first 25 people who sign up and join the ISSP will talk about the details
a little bit later on.
But just want to make sure that you all know about that special perk from today's discussion.
And thank you for that, Marine.
That's wonderful.
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
So, yeah, to your point about how important it is, essential really that we think of the
sustainability functions in all sectors really.
It's something I wrote about in Y on Earth and specifically in that section, that third
section that dealt with work and earning and our engagement with the economy and really
thinking about how we create more cyclical and circular and regenerative economies and
economic behavior in the broad sense of the term and that many of us, regardless of whether
we're accountants or communications specialists or educators or manufacturers, whatever it may
be that we're doing in terms of technical skill sets.
More and more of us are engaging in sustainability and stewardship through all those different
channels.
And it seems that you are at such an amazing nexus point of that fast emerging and growing
phenomenon.
Absolutely.
And our members are engaging in a key part of what they do is work to engage others in
their organizations or in their communities and try and figure out how to get everybody
involved in this because it's not something that one person in an organization can solve.
Everybody has a part to play, whether in a business, if you're the purchasing manager,
then you need to be thinking about where are the products you are purchasing coming from?
How have they been sourced?
Are they renewable products?
Are they compostable?
What happens to them at the end of their life cycle?
How are they being produced?
Is there slave labor or child labor being used to produce them?
Is there a lot of pollution generated when they're produced?
The purchasing person has to think about it, but also the HR person has to think about
it because they have to make sure that everyone in the company is trained on sustainability
and understand how it fits into what they're doing.
Everyone has a piece that they can play.
What's really wonderful is the training courses that we have help people understand where
they fit into that, but also what they can do.
Right now, we're running a course on sustainability planning.
Next month, we're doing one on sustainability management systems because it's one thing
to do with plan.
If you don't have a system in place to actually implement the plan and make sure that you
then, any plan that you put in place, you then have to do it.
Then at the end, you have to check to make sure that you've had some results and revised
it.
There's a whole process for that.
The next step is on leadership skills, how you can be a change agent within your organization
or within your municipality.
That's part of what we do is empower the professionals to be able to make change.
It's so beautiful and to be able to provide expertise and methodologies that help folks
really up their game, up level their capability is obviously such a huge value.
It's clear that the market is shifting more and more in this direction and that folks
who have not only the credentials, but the access to the additional resources and capabilities
are going to have additional competitive advantage out there, basically.
Absolutely.
In fact, on our website, we have recordings of webinars that we've done recently with
potential holders in different industries.
We have one for people that are in higher education, one for credential holders in local
government and two that are for consultants.
They talk about what they feel is the value of the credential in furthering their career,
but also in how getting the credentials helps them to better understand what they were
doing and have better skills to do it.
Actually, they also talk a little bit about their journey, how they got to those points
in their life.
That's actually a lot of fun to listen to as the trajectory of it.
We have one person who got a degree in philosophy and now we have a facilities manager.
We have someone else who got a degree in religion.
It's just amazing.
There are people that got degrees in engineering or in journalism.
It's really an amazingly diverse group and it's just fun to listen to how they got where
they are today.
I think it inspires everyone to see that they can do it as well.
So beautiful.
Well, I guess we could quip that perhaps all roads can lead to sustainability and hopefully
will.
Yes, and they all need to.
Absolutely.
I agree.
Let me ask you about your journey, speaking of journeys.
How did you end up as the executive director of ISSP?
Tell us about that.
You know, I started off an information management and was doing database work for the USEPA,
particularly in the area of hazardous materials management.
So they had a database on that.
And I decided I needed to go get a degree in that area because I didn't really, I knew
it was bad stuff but I didn't really understand all the issues with it.
So I went back to school to get a master's in hazardous materials management in civil
and environmental engineering.
And while I was there at Sufts University, there was a group of people working on sustainable
community indicators.
And I thought, oh, indicators, I do data.
I know how about that.
And what I wanted to do is, you know, the problem with data and indicators is people go,
oh, we've got to measure everything so we know what to do next.
And the problem is you never have enough data.
And if you spend all of your time collecting more and more data, you know, what I call feeding
the data monster, you'll never actually make a decision.
You'll never actually start doing anything.
So I said, you know, I could help communities that are working on sustainability, help them
think about why they want to measure something and help them define the real goals they want
and then what's the least amount of data that they want to collect.
So I ended up writing the guy, the sustainable community indicators and then did a lot of
work with the US EPA.
I did a bunch of training trainers around the country on what is the sustainability indicator
and how do you use it and, you know, how do you decide what the right ones for your community
also work with the US Forest Service.
And then I got involved with, I was a member of IASP and I got involved with some work
with two of the founders put together, a sustainability assessment tool that was very
high level.
And I called a cross between a Myers-Briggs organization and a reading readiness because
what it does is it looks at an organization and says, you know, of all the different
functions you have in the organization, you've got senior management, HR and purchasing
and facilities managers.
They're all doing something and they all have different roles to play and each of those
roles has different levels that they could be at and they could be at, you know, not even
starting or they could be really, you know, well along the path as sort of a maturity model.
And so I started using that model with a bunch of my clients and it was really wonderful
because we could benchmark and say, okay, you know, in this particular area on say purchasing,
you're doing really well because you're thinking about it.
But you know, in terms of educating your employees or having a vision for the corporation,
you're really not that far.
So it was a wonderful way to help organizations figure out where they could really have the
most impact or what they really needed to work on most.
And the point was not that everybody would get every one of those things to be perfect,
right?
You know, the example I always use is, I'm never going to be a good basketball player.
I'm too short and I'm really not that coordinated.
But there's other things that I do really well, right?
And so that's what sustainability is about.
Every organization has different ways that they're impacting the world in terms of sustainability
and that's what they should focus on.
So if you're a law firm, your water use is probably minimal.
But you may have a lot of pay per use or you may have a lot of travel.
Whereas if you're a food processor, your water use and your food waste is probably really high,
you may not have a lot of travel, right?
So it helps to people.
So this is actually the longer story, right?
So I got involved in that and used that tool.
And now that's actually one of the tools that I as the team has.
And then it's four and a half years ago, one of the founders who was the executive director
at the time decided to step down and I threw my hat in the ring.
And here I am.
Wonderful.
Well, I want to ask you a couple of questions getting a bit more into some of the
details around the value and the services that you offer.
But before I do that, I just, I have to ask, and I do this with some of my
consulting clients, whether they're executives of larger companies and organizations or
entrepreneurs with early stage ventures.
Outside of your work, part of your life, in your personal part of your life,
how do you incorporate some of the opportunities for stewardship and sustainability that
perhaps reflects what you're doing professionally?
In other words, if we were to take a walk with Marie on the weekend or something,
what does that look like?
Well, actually, you'd have to have a bike.
Okay.
Because what I like to do is take bike rides and I actually do try to bike to work.
I also, I'm more apt to be walking in the woods than going shopping.
And one of the things that I've been doing over the last few years is down-cliving.
Figuring out what's the least I need in terms of material goods to really survive.
Because in fact, it's the people you have around you and the friends and families that you
have that really makes life worth living.
You know, this idea of, you know, she who has the most toys wins when they die, it's like,
no, it's not it.
It's the friends and family that are around you.
So, you know, that's the, and, you know, obviously things like reducing water use,
reducing waste.
I try to only buy organic food.
And although it don't, the moment has my own garden.
I actually just moved to Pittsburgh.
And when I was living in Connecticut, I was part of a CSA.
I was one of the managing organizers of a CSA.
It was providing organic food to the local community.
Oh, that's wonderful.
That is just wonderful.
Thank you for sharing that.
I can, I can form a picture in my mind as you're describing that.
Beautiful.
And of course, in Pittsburgh, there are plenty of wonderful forested walking trails.
I understand it's one of the more forested park
rich cities in our country.
There are some great parks.
Yes.

I want to ask, you know, as you're building this global network of experts, practitioners and
folks who are upping our games, what are one or two of the biggest challenges that you're seeing
for us professionals as well as for our society's generally speaking?
You know, the biggest we actually just did a survey of all of our members and this is one of
the questions we asked them. And one of the biggest issues they said was the lack of awareness
of the size and the scope of the sustainability issues and the need for action right now. And this
is particularly a problem given the current political climate. You know, what we really need is more
collaboration and cooperation in order to solve some of these problems. You know, and on the
environmental side, we've got massive hurricanes and wildfires and floods and you're in
Pittsburgh, we're having lots of landslides because of torrential rains. And so all of those
things are caused by the climate change. But we also have other things happening like a declining
pollinator populations, you know, honey bees. And the things that we need to pollinate the food that
we eat. And so this is changing our whole food ecosystem, which is going to be a problem. And then
on the social side, there are issues with increasing income inequality and lack of trust and cooperation.
And that's what makes a democracy function. And so we really need to start working on those and
and so getting awareness out to people and finding ways to talk to each other. So that's really
one of the biggest ones. The other issue is that a lot of people think that sustainability is all
about the environment. Right. And what I like to tell people is, you know,
Mother Nature is going to be around long after we're gone. Sustainability is really about our economic
and our social system. And we have to understand that it's a system. And so we have to figure out how do
we make our social system and our economic system work within the environmental system that's there.
Because, you know, it's the laws of nature that are really, you can't repeal them. Right. Gravity
exists. You can't repeal the law of gravity. And you can't change the way nature works. So we really
need to think about how do we change the economic and social system. Then
one of the important things is to realize the social aspects of it because poverty and income
inequality are really driving a lot of the issues that we have. You know, we in the US have a very
high standard of living. And it's not right for us to turn around to someone in a low-income country
and say, no, no, no, you can't you can't have any of the things that we have.
Especially if these people can't, you know, feed their families. If you can't
care for your basic needs, take care of your kids, you're not going to care if the factory starts up
that's polluting the environment, right? Because that's a longer term issue. And you just want to
feed your kids so you want a job. Right. So we need to think about how do we make the economic
system and the social system fit together. So that's the other thing is that people not realizing
that social and economic issues are really the sustainability challenge. Another one is short-term
thinking. Yes. And a lack of a system of view. Right. Understanding that these things are connected.
You know, for example, in our in the corporate world, most companies are driven by quarterly earnings
reports. And that means it's really hard to make a decision that if we make this change to our
process, which is going to have a really great reduction in, say, carbon emissions are waste.
But it's going to be an economic payback that will take 10 years. Then they may not do it because
the shareholders are going to say, wait a minute, we need more profit. Right. So there's that short-term
thinking that we need to step back from and say, you know, it's okay. And that's actually one of
the things that's happening is there are companies called B-Corp's that are benefit corporations
being created where they're actually now, I don't know, like 40 states have a legislation that
allows them. And that's allowing companies to be set up so they can say, yes, we need to give
benefits to our shareholders, but we can also think of social and environmental benefits. And
that will count as well. So that's another interesting change that's happening. And then finally,
the last really major challenge that sustainability professionals have is making the business case
for sustainability. I was just talking about how do you put in some program in place that's
going to have a 10-year payback. Well, part of the problem is, we have these hurricanes and
floods and landslides and the cost of fixing all of that doesn't get factored into the price of
oil or the price of energy, you know, or the cost of goods. So any pollution that's created in
China to create low-cost goods that we then buy doesn't get factored into the price, but you know,
there are now some poor air quality days in California that are caused by pollution in China.
It's a system and we need to think about that. So how do we create these business cases
and be able to factor in what those are called externalities, how those costs that we don't usually
think of. So those are really the biggest sort of global problems. The individual problems for
the sustainability professionals themselves, you know, what is sort of isolation because a lot of
companies have one sustainability professional that's known to talk to. And that's one of the reasons
ISSP is a great organization because you can network with other people. You can talk about issues
you're having and someone will say, oh yeah, you know, I tried that, it didn't really work,
so I did this instead. So there's being able to work with other people,
expanding responsibility for sustainability, you know, getting it so it's not just, oh, you're
the sustainability director, you fix the problem. It's everybody's responsibility. So how do you
expand it and bring in all of the stakeholders and all of the people within the organization?
And that gets to changing corporate culture. And so that's another big challenge that the
individual has. How do you manage culture change within organizations? And then there's just resources.
You know, getting the resources to put new projects in place, but also to maintain projects
that you've already had going for a few years. And this is actually something that we hear in the
poll because we put a whole lot of effort, oh, you know, put a whole lot of money into building this
bridge and then didn't think about how much it was going to cost to maintain it. So we need to
be better at thinking about this. Again, that gets to the long-term planning. Yeah.
Long-term thinking is building the road is great, but then we're just going to cost to fix it.
